description:
Echinococcus granulosus is a species of tapeworm that belongs to the genus Echinococcus. It is a parasitic flatworm that can cause a serious zoonotic disease known as cystic echinococcosis or hydatid disease in humans and various other mammalian hosts.

The adult form of E. granulosus lives in the small intestine of canine definitive hosts, such as dogs, wolves, and foxes. The tapeworm produces microscopic eggs that are released in the feces of the definitive host. When the eggs are ingested by an intermediate host, such as sheep, goats, or humans, the eggs hatch and the larval form (called a hydatid cyst) develops in various organs, most commonly the liver and lungs.

The hydatid cysts can grow over several years, causing significant health problems in the infected intermediate host. Humans can become infected through the accidental ingestion of E. granulosus eggs, usually due to close contact with infected canine definitive hosts or contaminated food and water.

Echinococcosis is a significant public health concern in many parts of the world, particularly in areas where sheep and dog rearing are common. Diagnosis and treatment of the disease can be challenging, and effective control measures, such as deworming of dogs and proper disposal of animal waste, are essential to prevent the spread of this parasitic infection.
